Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	When you have been treated by a physician for this corruption, and the cure is not accepted: and you see the corruption spreading to the member, which does not remit anything: then it is necessary to cut that member as far as the corruption goes, so that the weak one may be eased through that from death, or from the greater defect of the member.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	The sign that is affected by this is the one that diminishes the member until it is thought to have been burned by fire or putrefied after being blackened: until the putrid matter spreads throughout the entire body, until the membrane surrounding the member is reached.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore, when the incision is made, and similarly if the cause of putrefaction is from the striking of certain venomous animals such as scorpions, sharks, rats, and the like: then, the membrane surrounding the member should be cut away.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If putrefaction or striking is at the end of the finger, then cut the finger, and do not leave any room for putrefaction to spread until it reaches the remaining hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if it happens in the hand, then cut it from the root of the finger, and do not leave any room for putrefaction to spread until it reaches the shoulder.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it spreads to it, then cut the arm at the elbow joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	However, if you see putrefaction passing through it, and it is near the elbow joint, then it is the death of the weak.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And to take care of this beyond that, is the quantity of virtue.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And similarly when putrefaction spreads to the toe, then cut it at one of the nodes: and if it reaches the sole of the foot, then cut off the entire foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	However, if it ascends to the knee, then cut the thigh at the joint.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	But if putrefaction has already spread above the knee, then there is no courage left except for release and leaving the weak to die.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the way of cutting or binding the member is to tighten the ligament in the lower part, which you want to cut, and tighten another ligament above the place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	He extends one of the serving ligaments to the lower part, and extends another ligament above to the top.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	He then separates the meat that is between the two ligaments with the Spatumil, until the whole meat is exposed.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then it is applied or squeezed.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And it is necessary to cover all sides of the linen bandage, and do not touch the healthy place with the knife: and the wound of the injured part should be heated.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	If however, the flow of blood inside while operating, then cauterize the place slightly: or put some small wound-healing pus above it.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your medication until it is completed.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then tie the wounded limb with the suitable ligament and take care of it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I tell you that this happens to the man in his foot, this is the same thing that I tell you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	That is, because the blackness happens in his foot, with the ash that is similar to the combustion of fire: and the corruption happens first in his thumb, until it begins to affect the whole foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	Therefore the man himself cured himself, after he saw the corruption happening to his member with the violence of its pain, which he found with its ash and combustion: and he applied it at the joint, and he was healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed, it happened to him the same corruption in his index finger of his hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	Therefore he came to me, and I tried to recover that excess with the same thing that I put on his hand with medicines after the purification of his body: and the excess was not repercussed, and it began to go into another finger: until it began to corrupt in his hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	He called me to extend my hand for the incision: and I did not want to do it, hoping that he would benefit from the repercussion of this excess: and I was also afraid of the death of this incision on his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	For the virtue of the man was above the accident.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	After he despairing of me, returned to his earth: and came to me because he had hurried, and extended all his hand: and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I did not bring this story unless it is an aid for the above that falls from the species of this disease: and so it has a meaning by which it is said, and according to which it is done.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	Regarding the care of Sinuum, and the quality of clisterization with medicines.
Caput XC.	Chapter 102.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When an abscess occurs in some fleshy parts, and the space of the abscess is prolonged until the collection of pus is made: then it either ruptures or is perforated, and goes out what is in it, and leaves a watery place as if it were water: and the skin which is over it is like fine linen which has been woven: and it does not reach the end of its corruption in its corruption, nor impresses on the mouth, nor in the nerves, nor in the ligaments: therefore it is right to call it Sinus: and it is not called Fistula: but if the space of its abscess is prolonged until it impresses the corruption on something of these parts, then it is called Fistula, or zuken.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And the care of it is to incise this skin completely as it revolves: and especially when it has been made fine, and has been made like linen: and I trust that it does not adhere to its place because of its corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	If you indeed hope that the skin adheres and does not follow the corrupting final connection: and if there is thickness in the skin from flesh, then care for it with Clister: and it is, as you consider, towards the Sea.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large and the pus that comes from it has a fetid odor: then apply Clister with the Egyptian medicine, which is a mixture of vinegar, oil, and zinc, and parts are received equally, and are aggregated into a vase: and they are boiled over fire until the medicine reddens: and it will come to a thick consistency like honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from it what is necessary for you: and dissolve it with water and honey, and apply Clister with it to the Sea: and close the orifice of it, and release the medicine into it in an amount of two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract it with the expression: do this for several days until the Sea is cleansed and the fetid odor is removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And when it is Clistered with ash and water, when this medicine is not present to you: and it is, as you consider, that you take ash from burning wood or ash from burnt oak: and discard over it the water.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then suck it, and apply Clister with it, until you are confident that the Sea has been washed clean.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	If the patient is not able to tolerate the medicine of Egypt, nor the ash and water, then apply Clister with water and honey, which has already been mixed with something from crushed zinc.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or apply Clister with honey and wine, because of the property of honey, which cleans and washes: and the wine makes the Sea adhere, especially when there are superfluities of styptic and drying in the wine.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you perform that several times, and I am confident that the sin of corruption is already removed: then clysterize it with that which you do when you cause flesh to be born in it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And it is, as if you take from plaster dyafinicon: and dissolve it with rose-colored oil, and wine-acetic: or clysterize it with some medicines, and ointments of others, whose properties I have written in the book on ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	If the sin of the orifice is a strict one, in which the cannula of the clyster does not enter: then enlarge it with iron almost: or place in it the limb in unguentum Egyptian, or in unguentum basilicon, until it is enlarged.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly if it is also an enlarged orifice: then gather the lips of it with the suture: and let out from it that quantity which it enters into the clyster without addition.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And similarly if the orifice through which the pus runs is eleved to the upper parts: then dry it in a lower place that is in it, so that the pus may run down from it: for when the pus is compressed in depth, it prevents the flesh from being generated in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	If it is not possible for you to dry the sin lower down according to what you wish: then dare, as if you were preparing the member by preparation, so that the pus runs out from it with facility according to what is prepared for you.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Dare, as if you were not retaining anything at all from the pus entirely: and take the solidified medicines which are put over the sign, compatible with what you wish.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And extend them over the linen bandage.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the bandage be of such a size that there is communication to the whole sin.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then make an incision with small notches in the direct orifice of the sinus, almost at the orifice of the sinus.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then extend another application of gentle ointment over the cloth according to the size of the foramen: and place it over the position far from the orifice of the sinus, so that the pus would come out from there: and you will not remove a large cloth unless after a few days one.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	He who is above the orifice of the sinus is he whom you remove at all times, so that what aggregates in it from pus may go out: and to know whether that which runs out is much, or little: or digested, or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And when you again consider the place of the sinus of his own, does the lord of it feel the pain there, or not feel any pain in it, and is there not an apostema in it, or is there not an apostema in it.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When you extend your medication in this way, and see what comes out over the orifice of the sinus, then you know that the sinus is adhered, or approximates to the adhesion: then you can loose it in the morning, or on the third day: and when you loosen it, then change another cloth, and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	But if it comes out from the sinus after a long distance, then do not despair of its adherence, because the healing of his is approaching, for there are men who slow down the generation of their flesh in their wounds, and there are those who act against him.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	But if it comes out from the sinus after many days of indigested pus, then you know that the sinus does not adhere.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	If then the adherence of the sinus is slow and prolonged, and then add to the drying of the medicines, let the doctors make them, so that they are in the substance of their humid and in their virtue their dryness, just as unguent dyafinicon, when it adds superfluitas additionis ex zegi.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	After the last significant part is treated, it is that you should take a ointment of dafine, and it dissolves with rose oil, and is poured over it an old wine equal in substance to itself.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then close it with this, and use it alone.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And it does the same action when there is not a dafine ointment present for you, honey, when you extract it, until it thickens, and you use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh, and frankincense, and olibanum: grind them all together, and put that on the honey while it is over the fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then lay a linen cloth over it, and bind it with a cord around the belly: and when the melted honey is thickened, put a layer of it on the outside of the cloth, and then place the cloth over it and bind it.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And when a long aristolochia is given in that, and the heavenly lily roots, and the lily itself: and herb flour, and centaury, are mixed together,
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Either grind them simple, or mixed together, grind them, and put that on the honey which I will give you, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If the wound does not heal and prolongs the belly, and you know that there is corruption in the depth of it, or that it has made an impression on the bones, or on other hard parts, or on the ligaments: then treat it according to the treatment of fistulas, as I have mentioned before.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	¶ About the cure of Panaritis and the roughening of the nail, and the addition of a cut to the digit, and the section.
Caput XCI.	Head 11.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Panaritis is a blister that is born under the pollex of the hand, or of the foot, and may be born in other digits.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When this is prolonged and neglected in the care of the patient, and is treated with hot aspersions: or it corrupts, and emits pus, until it corrodes the root of the nail: and perhaps it corrupts the whole, and perhaps it spreads the corruption to the mouth, until it has an offensive odor: and the tip of the digit becomes swollen, and its color becomes black.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When you care for it thus, when we say in division, and does not share your care: then it is necessary to burn the remaining superfluity with iron all over the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the nail after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	For a cauterant is hard on the nail.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If however the mouth is sound, and the nail is also sound, and the additions to the nail begin to compress the flesh towards the interior, and begin to hurt it, then it is necessary to place a thin layer of radium under the angle of the nail which presses the flesh, and push it upwards: and burn away the remaining flesh with medicines that are burning, until the whole of it is removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointments until it is healed.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If however the corruption has already settled in the mouth, then it is necessary to burn the mouth and remove it: for the mouth is never healed while the corrupted part remains in it.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see corrosion and corruption increasing in the digit, then burn it in one boil, according to the rememoration of what was previously said.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it is healed.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If however the nail has an abrasion or a blow: and it happens that there is pain in the vein, then it is necessary to insert a veinlet at first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then scrape off the nail with a sharp knife slice, transferred from above to the eye.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And guard against it being cut through to the flesh beneath the nail, for you are causing this by the section that is on the weakest pain, and it will be a cause of adding new flesh in that place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then attend to the place with that which soothes the pains.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	But the thumb that is born in some human hands may be entirely fleshy, and perhaps there are bones in some of them, and perhaps there is a nail in it, and some are born from the root of the joints, or it is a growth of its nodes on some of its digits.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	Therefore, that which is born from some of the nodes of the digits does not move, and that which is born at the joint of the digit may perhaps move.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	Therefore, that which is fleshy among them is easy to section.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	That which you do is to cut it at the root of its own self with a sharp knife.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	But the treatment of its growth that is in the root of the joints is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Therefore, abstain from cutting it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	But in that which is born at the last node of the digit, then it is necessary to cut into its flesh with a round section up to the bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then sharpen the bone with one of those saws that are convenient for that.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then attend to it until it is healed.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	But the consolidation which happens to the digits is often due to the growth of man, that is, it is born with him, or from the consolidation of the wound, or from the combustion of fire, and suchlike.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	It is therefore necessary to allow that consolidation to take place, until the fingers return to their natural shape.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place a thread between them, or soaked wool in rose oil: so that they do not become too quickly united, and separate the threads: or place a thin sheet of plumbago between them, until the location consolidates according to what is appropriate.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And similarly if the consolidation occurs between some fingers and the palm, then dry that consolidation, according to what is prepared and becomes the shape of the member.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	¶ Of the Incision.
Caput XCII.	Head 122.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	The veins are often enlarged, heavy, and full of melancholic superfluities that occur in many parts of the body: and the most frequent of these is found in the legs, especially in the legs of those who walk and labor, and carry.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore it is necessary to give a rubbing of the body from black bile, with a strong rubbing.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then make a bleeding on the patient's basilica vein.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The treatment of these is according to two methods.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	They are unclosed, so that they may heal, and black blood is drawn out.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And another method is to make the vein swell, and draw out all of the blood.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The section of it is according to this method.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	First embroider the thigh with hot water, until the thick, feces-like blood is dissolved.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then tighten the weak thigh from its upper part of the hip, until the lower part of the knee.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then dry the vein in one place, or two, or three, by wide section.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then, that is, remove the blood from your hand with the bloodletting instrument from the lower part of the thigh to the top, and first, it should be done on the weakest one.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then, remove the nail from the foot until the amount of blood you see is sufficient and can be endured by the weakest.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then tie it: and tell him to fast from foods that produce black bile: and again, let there be an evacuation and bloodletting when the veins are full, and do not harm the weakest.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	The ablution of this part is done in this way.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Shave the weak leg if there are many hairs on it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then introduce it into the bath: or rub it on the thigh of the weak one with hot water until it reddens and the veins become engorged, or exercise strength training if there is no bath nearby, until the member becomes warm.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then shave the skin in a direct section along the length of the vein, or in the last part of it at the knee, or in the lower part of it at the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with tweezers and scrape the vein from all sides until it is visible to the touch, and it is at the appearance you see it turn red to black.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When it comes out of the skin, it seems like a string or cord.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then introduce under it the radium, until it is abluted and comes out of the skin: suspend it with a black cat's claw, gently.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then shave another section near that one about three digits wide.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape the skin from the upper part of the vein until it is visible.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then remove it from it with the radium as you did, and suspend it with another black cat's claw, as you did at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then make another cut, or more cuts, if you need them for that.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then separate the tissue, and cut the last section at the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then pull it out to the section that is above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do this until it comes out from the section that is above it, or from all higher sections, until it goes out completely: then cut it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	But if it does not obey you to extract and separate: then insert a knife with strong wire doubled, and tie it, and pull it out of that: or insert the radium under it, and rotate your hand over all parts until it goes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And be careful not to cut it.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it is cut, it becomes difficult for you to separate it gently, and it goes in above the weakest part of it.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When you pull it out completely: then place over the wound a piece of linen dipped in wine and rose oil, or rose oil: and take care of it until it heals.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	If the vine is contracted, having twists which make it to be applied to parts, and not as we said according to the straightness: then it is necessary to place above it over all the twists of it, and locate the involutions of its own.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend it with a garter until you separate it completely: and be careful not to cut the vein or wounds above your section, for it will be difficult for you to separate or pull it out.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Therefore keep your wisdom.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The form of the cut that heals the vine.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The form of the blind man's eye.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It is not like the others of the blind, neither is it sharp at the extremities, so as not to wound the vein: and it has a coarse bend, but a gentle one: for if it were subtle, it would cut the vein with its own subtlety: moreover, it is superfluous coarseness, as we said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	Extraction of the Thigh Vein
Caput XCIII.	Chapter 37.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the thighs on earth, such as in hot springs, and in the hot lands of Arabia, and in dry and hot lands, in few tender regions, that is, in which there is neither grass nor tree.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is generated in other parts of the body besides the thighs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	Indeed, its generation is from putridity which occurs under the skin, just as occurs in the bodies of snakes and ascaris worms, and the worms that are generated between the skin and the flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And a sign of the onset of this vein is that which occurs in the thigh with inflammation of the skin.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then it becomes infected.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to exit from the place of its infection, as if it were the root of a plant, or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When therefore you see the end of it, then it is necessary to suspend a lead weight on that branch, whose weight is from a drachm to two drachms and one grain, and release the hanging lead from the thigh.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	When therefore something exits from it towards the outside, suspend that in lead, and that branch.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	If however it is extended for a long time, then a part of it will break off, and suspend the remainder.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut it off before it has completely exited.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut it off, it contracts and enters into the flesh: and it causes an abscess to be formed, and putridity in the place, and a bad ulcer.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it is necessary to treat it with great care, and to draw it out gradually, until it has completely exited from its ultimate end, and nothing remains of it in the body: and from this very vein some people are able to draw out, which is in length five palms and ten.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	It has already become evident to me because he escaped from the man of XX palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	However, if it happens to you at the time of your medicine: then insert the root into its opening, and make a long hole through the body, until all that is in it of matter has come out: and administer putrefaction to the site with medicines for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then take care of the healing of the aposteme.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	Indeed, this vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears in the joint of the foot, or in the foot itself: and many openings happen to it, and they issue from all openings a branch.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Therefore, take care of it as we have said in the division, and with what has been said before.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	¶ Regarding the sectioning of the vermes generated under the skin, and it is called bouina ailment.
Caput XCIIII.	Head 143.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This ailment is called in our land the Aegritudo bouina: because it happens very often to bouids, and it is a small worm, which is born between the skin and the flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it goes through the whole body, going up and down: and it is shown to the sense during his walking with his member to his member, until it breaks at whatever place it breaks into the skin, and it issues.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from some putrefaction of humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	So do worms and snakes, that is, pinworms, and ascarids in the belly.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And he fears from its malice.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when he himself goes through the body, and rises to the head, and becomes evident to him, and it issues, and it destroys the eye: and this happens often.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	When you therefore wish to treat him and draw it out, then this is not done unless at his walking and his own sensation.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	It is necessary therefore, to draw that which is above him, and that which is beneath him with a strong constriction bandage.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry that which is over it, and pull it out.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	If it is driven into the flesh, and you do not find it: then place the cauterium above the place with fire until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And that which is greater than what you fear, is a corruption of it, which corrupts the eye, just as we said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	If however you see it already exuded near the eye in the head: then draw that which is under it beneath the good tightening eyebrow.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry that which is over it, and pull it out.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is necessary that he use a weak cleansing of his body, when the physicians are curing the putrid humors with bad medicines.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And let him beware of foods that generate putrefaction for himself.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	¶ About the section over the sickness of Nakir.
Caput XCV.	Head 45.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This sickness is called Nakir in our land: and it is a pain that happens in some members, and then it changes from one member to another.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And I myself have seen it, according to what I am telling you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I am called to a weak woman in some wools.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And he detaches his arm, and I see a small inflammation in the weak thread of his arm.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after an hour has passed, I see one inflammation coming up with the fire, just as a child comes up, going to his shoulder higher than it can be: just as silver runs when it runs from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	The pain then receded from that place and became fixed in the hip.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then he sat for an hour, and it ran into the rest of the body until it became inflamed in the arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then he told me that it was rotating throughout his entire body, according to what I saw.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I was amazed at the speed of its rotation from one member to another.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	Indeed, I had not seen this kind of eye ailment before in this way.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	However, I have seen many who found the pain to rotate from one member to another: and I did not see it as a woman sees it.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	I do not think this to be so, unless it is because of the fact that she was one of those women who detect venom from dry bodies: therefore, it appears to the senses that the vapor has rotated.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	It is necessary, therefore, that they do not appear according to this reason in those who are delicate and in dry bodies, and in humid bodies.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When you are treating this, and the patient feels that pain: then if it is visible to your eye as I said, then tighten above it, and run quickly beneath it: and dry it above it until it departs from the confined vapor: and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	If you do not see it with your eyes: then treat it with the movement of the body, and with that which expels the vapors, and compresses them with the smelling pills, and the pills of serapin, and such like.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	¶ About the extraction of the Sagittarius.
Caput XCVI.	Chapter 56.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	The Sagittarius is divided according to the species of its form and the location where it falls from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	The diversity of their teeth is great: for among them there are those that have large and pointed ones, and small ones: and sharp ones, and smooth ones.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And among them there are those that have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And among them there are those that have tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And among them there are those that have stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	Those which are according to the limbs in which they lie, are according to two modes.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	Or if the limbs are from the principal members, like the brain, and the heart, and the spleen, and the lungs, and the intestines, and the uterus, and suchlike.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When therefore the dart falls into any of these limbs, and you see signs of death which I will tell you later, then it is necessary to extract the arrow from that limb, for death follows it in many dispositions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when you do not see those signs of evil, and the arrow is not hidden deep in the limb, then take out the very dart, and care for the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	For when the dart falls into the brain, and pierces the mouth, and goes out through the siphon which is over the brain, it is: for there happen from thence sodorrhea, and scotomy, and vertigo, and redness in the eyes, and inflation, and redness of the tongue, and spasm, and confusion of the intellect, and diarrhea.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood may issue from the nostrils, or from the ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech is cut off, and the voice is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And water comes out from the place of the wound, like white fluid.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And it issues from there like the water of flesh.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If then these signs appear to you, then desist from treatment, and extract the arrow if it does not emerge.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	When the arrow falls into the heart, these signs are: that which is near the left breast: and it feels as if it is fixed in hard matter, not in soft.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the arrow's motion is similar to that of the pulse: and it runs from the black blood vessel.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And it follows the cold at the extremities, and the cold sweat, and the syncope.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	Know then that death has likely occurred far from doubt.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And when the arrow pierces the lung, the sign is the spongy blood from the vein: and the wound that follows the neck, bleeds, and changes to a weak color.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And the spirit exhales a great, high breath: and it seeks the cold air's attraction.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	That if the arrow falls into the chest, which is in the breast: then it is near the ribs: and there is a great thirst with a painful shout, with a sigh: and all the muscles of the upper arms move.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if the arrow falls into the stomach: then perhaps it will emerge from the vein of something undigested in the food.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if the arrow falls into the belly, and is felt there: something from the vein emerges, either feces, or dung, or a broken intestine.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	Therefore, there is no hope in its treatment, nor in the extraction of the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	That if the arrow falls into the bladder, and it emerges with urine: and something comes out from it to the outside, and the pain is greater on the weakest part: then you know that it is fatal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	Furthermore, the remaining parts such as the face, neck, throat, spatula, auxiliary tool, dorsal vertebrae, wishbone, leg, and thigh are healed according to various dispositions: when it does not find an arrow at the artery, or a nerve: and there is no sharp arrow.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I tell you that I have seen the essence of these arrows, as you understand through this treatment for your cure.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	That is, because an arrow fell into the tearful eye of a certain man, at the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	Therefore, I extracted it from the other side, under the fat of his ear: and he was cured, and it did not cause harm to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I extracted another arrow from a Jewish man, which fell into the fat of his eye under the lower eyelid: and the arrow was already hidden, and I did not succeed in extracting it except by the tip of its small branch, with which it adheres to the wood of it: and it was a large arrow from the bows of the Turks, with soft iron, in which there are no ears.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	Therefore, the Jewish man was cured, and it did not cause harm to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted another arrow from the throat of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And it was an Arabic arrow, and it is this one that has ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	Therefore, I held it over the same under two guides: and it was already submerged in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	Therefore, I was careful with it until I extracted it: and the Christian was cured.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I extracted another arrow from a man who fell into his stomach: and we thought that he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	After thirty days had passed and nothing had changed in his condition, I followed the instructions given to me by Albucasis and extracted the arrow. He recovered and no harmful event occurred to him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man who had fallen on the arrow in his back, and the bone was healed above it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	After seven years, the arrow was expelled from the root of his hipbone.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman who had fallen on the arrow in her belly, and the bone was healed above it, and the arrow remained inside her, and nothing had changed in her condition, and she did not find any harm in any of her natural operations.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man who had fallen on the arrow in his face, and the bone was healed above it, and the arrow remained inside him, and he did not find much pain: and similar cases many.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted the arrow from a man of the king's principals, who had fallen on it in the middle of his nose, and it had already inclined to the side of the left part: and the arrow was hidden entirely.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I am called therefore to care for him after the fall of the arrow until three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I found the bone of the arrow strictly healed.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	Therefore I questioned it with gentle tension, and did not find it: and he himself found the prick and pain under his gold on the left side.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	Therefore I hoped that it was the prick from the end of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	Therefore I applied the place with plaster, in which the virtue attracted and digested, confident among me that it would be the place where the arrowhead would appear, and a sign of the arrow would be visible to me so that I could cut on it: and no accidental event occurred in the place, meaning that the arrow had reached the place.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	He should then be constantly bandaged for many days: and the wound does not become worse, and the flesh has healed over in the meantime: but he remains weak from the extraction for some days, until he feels a shaft one day in his own nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me that.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	I then applied sharp medicinal ointment over it for many days, until it is open: and when I touch it, and feel the tip of the subtle shaft that clings to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added to the opening of the wound with that sharp ointment, until the tip of the shaft is clearly visible: and it passed by me within about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then after the wound was enlarged, and it might be possible for me to insert thumbs into it, and move it, and not obey the exit: then I did not stop sharpening and engineering over it with such methods of ingeniousness, until I succeeded on a day with thumbs made according to their form, according to which they wish the end of the fingers to be, until I extracted it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And indeed doctors judge that the nose cartilage does not restore.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	Therefore he restored it, and the wound was healed and solidified, and he became healthy in full strength without anything harming him at all.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you about the quality of the extraction of that shaft: so that you may set this rule and meaning over what I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	For the parts and distinctions of this art are not comprehended by narration: nor does that book comprehend it, and a wise artificer compares with little to much: and when he finds a new operation and a new instrument among the descents of things foreign to this art, when they happen.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I declare that arrows do not depart from the parts where they are fixed, except in two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or through attraction from the place from which it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or on the opposite side of the other part.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And those that depart from where it entered are either an arrow going into flesh, and is attracted and goes out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	That is, if it does not submit to the exit from the hole from which it fell: then it should release it some days, until the decayed flesh around it allows the attraction and exit of the arrow.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And similarly, if it is fixed in bone, and does not submit to the exit from you: then release it also some days: and then bring it back with the attraction and movement every day, until it goes out.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	That is, if it does not submit to the exit after a day: then it should be drilled around the arrow in the bone from all sides with a sharp tool, until the arrows are enlarged.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then attract it and pull it out.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	But if the arrow is fixed in the bone of the head, and has already entered into one of the ventricles of the brain, and some of those things that I have mentioned seem to be unwell: then stop the attraction of the arrow, and release it, until it is equal after a few days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow pours into the sinus, then death will not be prolonged to him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed but only in the bones, and has not yet reached the sinus: and remains weak for a few days, and nothing unfortunate happens to it from those things: then the ingenuity in the attraction of the arrow and its removal.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	But if it is fixed tightly and does not submit to the attraction: then apply a sharp tool around the arrow as I have told you: then care for the place until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If, however, the arrow has already become concealed within the body and is hidden and concealed from sensation, then seek it out when you attempt.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If, however, you perceive it, then draw it out with some instruments that are suitable for its attraction.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If, however, you cannot draw it out due to the constriction of the wound and because of the length of the arrow in the deep part: and there is no mouth, nor nerve, nor vein: then seek it above, until the wound is amplified and it is possible to draw out the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	If, however, the ears to which it is tied have any, then free the flesh fixed in them from all sides, by every means you can think of and by other means as well, if it cannot be drawn out by extension of the flesh in the fracture of the ear, and by its twisting, until it is drawn out.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And when you administer the extraction of the arrow, in whatever place it is, then use the twisting of your hand with needles to all parts, until you draw it out: and with the finest subtlety of the end, so that the arrow does not break, and it be difficult for you to attract it and its extraction.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If, however, you cannot draw it out from the same hour, then let it be for some days until the putrefied that are around it putrefy.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then try it again: for then the flow of blood will turn against you, so administer what I said for the care in the chapter of it: and protect your virtue from the wound of the vein, or the nerve, or the cord.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And use all the means you can think of for the drawing out of the arrow: and let it be with facility, and tranquility, or slowness, and firmness, as I have told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	It is necessary that you act when you draw the arrow, that it be weak according to the figure, according to which was at the case of the arrow in itself.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	For it is more severe.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	But if that is not possible for you, then administer what is possible from the figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	But the arrow that is going out from the opposite part of another thing, or already goes out something to the outside: or it makes a bulge at the end of the arrow through the sense of the upper part of the skin nearby, and you see it prominent: then cut over it, and it should be a section according to the quantity that they take in the screws.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then draw it: for it itself makes it easy to come out.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	But if it is held in the bone, then twist your hand according to the roundness, until the arrow prints in the bone, and enlarges itself: then draw it.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: release it for a few days: then try it again until it goes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	If the wood of the arrow is in it, then drive it with that.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	But if the wood of the arrow has fallen, and you want to give a push: then insert the pointed instrument into it so that its concavity reaches the end of the arrow: then drive it with it.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	But if the arrow is concave, then drive it with the instrument that is being inserted into it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	For the arrow goes out through that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	But if the arrow is poisoned, then it is necessary that you cut the whole flesh in which the venom is, if it is possible for you to do that.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then take care of it as it comes to that.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	If an arrow is falling into the chest, or into the belly, or into the womb, or on the side: and it is near to that which you touch when you probe, and it is possible for you to cut above it: then cut it, and be careful not to make a venous cut, or a nerve cut, and extract it.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then examine the wound, if you see, and take care of that, until it heals.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form of the arrowhead, from which they extract the arrows.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	The ends should be similar to the face and snout, which are made like iron: when they catch above the arrow, they do not let it go.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And they are of various kinds, large and small, and medium-sized, according to the size of the arrow and the flexibility of the wound, and the constriction of the wound.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The form of the impeller is a hook.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	The form of the impeller is a hook.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the hook-like end like a radius, so that its entrance into the arrowhead can be easily fitted with the impeller, and it is pulled out with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	The hook-like end of the impeller is a hook similar to the snout, so that its entrance into the arrowhead can be easily fitted with the impeller, and it is pulled out with it.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	¶ About Bloodletting of Veins.
Caput XCVII.	Chapter 157.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	The veins that are commonly bloodlet in the body are thirty.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	In the head there are sixteen: two pulsating veins, which are behind the ears and are called the two Herbs: and two arteries that appear in two temporal bones: and two veins that are in two lacrimal bags of the two eyes, which are called Aspicientes: and the prepared vein in the middle of the forehead: and a vein that is at the end of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	Two guides are located in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	Two veins are found in the upper lip.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	Two veins are located in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	These are called the Algesarch veins.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	Two veins are located under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	However, the veins that are punctured in the arms are five veins in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the Cephalic vein, and it comes from the side of the head: and it is called the vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	And the Fuscus vein.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	The middle vein is called the Median vein, and it is composed of the Basilic and Cephalic branches: and it is called the vein of the body.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	The Basilic vein is placed on the side of the domestic arm: and it is also called the Titillary vein.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And it is called the vein of the veins.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	The funis of the arm is placed on the shoulder: and it is the one through which puncturing occurs, and it is the one that appears above the fingertip with a visible attachment.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	The Salutevein is the vein that is between the annulus and the minimum: and it has two branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And there are three veins in the wrist and the foot.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is the vein that is under the fingertip, and it is cut from the side of the hand.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	The second one is the Saphenous vein, and its location is at the heel on the domestic side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The third one is the Nasal vein, and its location is at the heel on the non-domestic side.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And there are three other veins similar to these in the wrist.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	Dephlebotomy of two veins after the shoulders.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	The phlebotomy of two veins located after the shoulders is used for old catarrhs, hemigroans, sahafatis, and old wounds on the head.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is according to what I am saying.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is, as the head of the weak one is stretched: and the back of its head is rubbed in the place of two veins with good rough friction using a cloth.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then the weak one should tie his neck with a string until the two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And their locations are after the shoulders in two depressed places on the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Therefore, seek them with your thumb and where you feel the pulse of theirs with your thumb, there make signs with a candle.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take the phlebotomy cart and that is the one called Incident.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then insert it under the vein into the flesh until the phlebotomy reaches the mouth.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then separate your hand with the vein and flesh with the incision incident, and cut the vein with the flesh with the incident incision.
