Et praecipe infirmo, ut mundificet Mandibulas suas, et absoluat eas ad manducandum ad omnem partem.	And he commands the weak one, to cleanse his mandibles, and to free them for eating to all parts.
Et medicus aequet Mandibulam, et impellat Mandibulam, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And the physician can move the mandible, and presses the mandible, until it returns to its place.
Quod si difficilis sit reductio eius, praecipue si sunt ambae Mandibulae simul: tunc administra uaporationem cum aqua calida, et oleo, donec fiat facilis reductio ambarum: neque tardes reductionem ambarum omnino, sicut diximus.	What if however the return of it is difficult, especially if both mandibles are at once: then he gives the softening with hot water and oil, until a easy return of the inferior is made: and he does not delay the reduction of the inferior at all, as I said.
Cum ergo redeunt et aequantur, et clauditur os infirmi, et non mollificantur: tunc pone super eas puluillos pannorum, cum ceroto quod sit factum ex cera: et oleo rosato.	When they are cut and sutured, and the wound is closed without being softened, then place some pieces of beeswax above them, with a little thorn made of wax, and some rose oil.
Deinde ligetur cum facilitate cum ligamentis mollibus.	Then, it is applied with ease, with flexible ligaments.
Et sit somnus infirmi super dorsum suum: et caput eius sit stans inter duo puluinaria, ut non moueat ipsum ad dextram et sinistram: neque conetur, uel cogatur masticare aliquid: imo ponatur cibus eius sorbitio lenis, donec quando remouentur dolores, et nodatur Mandibula: tunc comedat quod uult, et administretur illud cum facilitate.	Then, a soft pillow is placed on the back of the patient, and the head of the patient is held between two pieces of beeswax, so that it does not sway to the right or left. It does not voluntarily chew or masticate anything, rather, a food of its choice is placed on its jaw, until the pain subsides and the jaw is sutured. Then, it eats what it wants, and the food is administered with ease.
Non laboret super operationem oris sui apud comestionem et potum, et oscitationem, donec nodetur Mandibula, et sanetur.	The patient does not labor over the operation of its own mouth during eating and drinking, and until the jaw is sutured, and healed.
Quod si difficilis fiat reductio duarum Mandibuiarum, quando dislocantur in hora aliqua, et non conuertuntur ad loca sua: tunc multotiens accidunt inde febres, et soda assidua: et fortasse soluitur uenter infirmi, et fortasse uomit choleram puram.	If it is difficult to reduce the two jaws when they are dislocated in a certain hour and do not return to their original position, then there may be many fevers and frequent sweating, and perhaps the weak intestines are loosened, and perhaps the sour choler is swallowed.
Cum ergo uides illud: tunc scias, quia est perditio, et multotiens moritur ille cui accidit illud in decem diebus.	When you see this, then you know that it is a loss, and that person dies in ten days.
¶ De reducione dislocationis Furculae, et extremitatis humeri.	Regarding the reduction of the shoulder joint dislocation and the extremity of the humerus.
Caput XXVI.	Head 26.
Furcula quidem non dislocatur ex latere intrinseco, propter continuationem suam cum pectore.	The shoulder joint, however, is not dislocated from the inside of the shoulder, because of the continuity of its bone with the chest.
Et dislocatur quandoque ad exteriora: et declaratur illud sensui.	And it is sometimes dislocated to the outside: and this is declared by touch.
Et restauratio eius est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat brachia sua.	And its restoration is such that it lies weakly on its back, and extends its arms.
Deinde coarta locum cum palma tua coartatione forti, nam ipsa redibit.	Then, the joint is placed in a strong position with your palm, because it will return.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stringe eam.	Then place the plaster over it, and the swabs, and tie it up.
Extremitates uero eius quae sequuntur cubitum, et continuantur cum eo, non dislocantur, nisi raro.	The ends of these, which follow the knee, and are continuous with it, are rarely dislocated.
Quod s dislocatur die aliquo: tunc oportet, ut reducatur et aequetur secundum quod diximus, et quod praeparatur tibi.	If it is dislocated on any day: then it should be reduced and made equal as we have said, and prepared for you.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam.	Then place the plaster over it, the swabs, and the tied-up one.
Et praecipe infirmo, adhaerere tranquillitati et quieti, donec sanetur.	And instruct the nurse to remain calm and quiet until it heals.
Et cum hac eadem curatione reducitur extremitas Humeri, quando separatur etiam a loco suo.	And when the same treatment is applied to the end of the arm, when it separates even from its own place.
¶ De reductione dislocationis Humeri.	¶ About the reduction of the shoulder dislocation.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27.
Scias, quod Humerus non dislocatur, nisi secundum tres modos.	You know that the shoulder is not dislocated except in three ways.
Quorum unus est, ut dislocetur ad partem titillici ad inferiora.	One of which is, that it be dislocated to the part of the shoulder-blade towards the lower part.
Secundus est, ut dislocetur ad partem pectoris.	The second is, that it be dislocated to the part of the breast.
Et fortasse dislocatur ad superiorem partem Humeri: et illud fit raro.	And perhaps it may be dislocated to the upper part of the shoulder: and this happens rarely.
Et non dislocatur ad posteriora, propter spatulam.	And it is not dislocated to the back, because of the nail.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora, propter neruos.	And it is not dislocated to the front, because of the nerves.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur et egreditur ad inferiora uersus titillicum: praecipue in illis, quorum carnes sunt paucae.	And it is most frequently dislocated and goes out to the lower part, opposite the shoulder-blade: especially in those, where the flesh is least.
Quoniam egrediur in eis uelociter, et ingreditur uelociter.	For it goes out quickly from them, and enters quickly.
In illis autem quorum carnes sunt multae, est econtrario illius, scilicet quia egreditur cum difficultate, et ingreditur cum difficultate.	But in those where the flesh is much, it goes out against it, because it goes out with difficulty, and enters with difficulty.
Et fortasse accidit quibusdam hominibus percussio, aut casus, et apostematur Humerus apostemate calido, et putatur propter illud, quia iam dislocatus est.	And perhaps it happens in some men by a blow, or accident, and the shoulder is broken off hot, and it is thought that it is dislocated because of that.
Oportet ergo, ut experiaris illud, donec stes super certitudinem eius, et tunc procedas in curatione eius.	You must then try this, until you are certain of it, and then proceed to treat it.
Et cognoscitur dislocatio, quando est ad inferiora uersus titillicum: et distinguas inter Humerum dislocatum, et humerum sanum.	And a dislocation is known when the head is turned towards the lower part of the shoulder; and you can distinguish between a dislocated humerus and a normal one.
Nam tu inuenis inter eos diuersitatem manifestam, et inuenis in capite Humeri concauitatem, et sub titillico apud tactum caput humeri quasi ipsum sit ouum: et non potest infirmus reducere manum ad aurem suam, neque mouere eam omnibus motibus.	For you will find a clear difference between them, and you will find a union in the head of the humerus, and at the point where the head of the humerus is touched, it seems to be one piece: and it cannot be easily moved by the weak hand to its own shoulder, nor moved at all by any motion.
Et similiter, si dislocatur uersus pectus, aut ad sursum: tunc inuenis manifestum tactum, neque occultatur.	And similarly, if the shoulder is dislocated to the side or upwards: you will find a clear touch, and it will not be hidden.
Et huius quidem dislocationis fit facilis reductio, quando est recens, aut infirmus est puer.	And this dislocation is easy to reduce when it is recent, or the child is weak.
Et reductio eius est, ut eleuet minister manum suam ad superiora.	And the reduction of this is that he should raise his own hand to the upper part.
Deinde pone tu pollices tuos sub titillico eius, et eleua iuncturam cum fortitudine ad sursum ad locum suum: et minister eleuet manum suam, et extendat eam ad sursum.	Then place your own hands under the head of it, and raise the joint with strength to the upper part of its own place: and he will raise his own hand and extend it upwards.
Deinde ponat eam inferius, ipse enim redit uelociter.	Then he will put it down lower, for he returns quickly.
Si autem non redit per illud quod diximus, et sunt a principio quo accidit dislocatio dies multi: tunc oportet, ut balneetur infirmus in aqua calida, et administretur embrocatio quae mollificat et lenit, sicut si decoquantur radices alteae, et foenugraecum, et mellilotum in aqua, et administretur.	But if he does not return by what I said, and the days that pass are many from the beginning of the dislocation: then it is necessary for the weak one to be bathed in hot water, and an ointment should be applied which softens and soothes, as if the roots of tall plants, such as garden radishes, and melilot, were being cut off and dipped in water, and the ointment is applied.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et ponatur sub titillico eius sphera et lana, quae sit aequalis inter lenitatem et stricturam.	Then the weak one should rise on his back, and a sphere and wool which is equal in softness to gentleness and strictness should be placed under the head of it.
Deinde ponat medicus calcaneum suum super spheram, et eleuet caput humeri cum uirtute, et attrahat manum infirmi ad inferiora.	Then the physician will place his heel upon the sphere, and he will lift up the head of the shoulder with gentleness, and he will attract the weak hand to the lower parts.
Et minister alius teneat caput infirmi, ut non moueatur ad inferiora: ipse namque redit statim.	And another shall hold the weak head, so that it does not move towards the lower parts: for he returns immediately himself.
Et si uis, reduc eum secundum modum hunc: et est, ut facias esse praesentem uirum qui sit longior infirmo, et stet a parte lateris, et intromittat humerum suum sub titillico infirmi: et eleuet titillicum eius ad superiora, donec sit infirmus suspensus in aere.	And if you wish, reduce it according to this manner: and it should be as if a stronger man were present, standing on the side, and he would insert his hand under the weak one, and he would lift up the weak one's hand to the upper parts, until it becomes weak and suspended in the air.
Et minister alius trahat manum infirmi ad inferiora uentris eius.	And another shall draw the weak hand of his towards the lower vents of him.
Si autem infirmus est leuis: tunc oportet, ut suspendatur cum eo aliquid aliud, ut grauet ipsum: nam redit dislocatio statim.	But if the weak one is close: then it is necessary that he hangs something else with him, so that it grieves him, for he returns to dislocation immediately.
Et reducitur etiam secundum modum alium: et est, ut figatur in terra lignum longum, cuius caput sit rotundum figura: sicut manica mortarii: quod non sit grossum, neque subtile.	And it is also reduced according to another manner: and it should be as if a long log of wood, whose head is round figure, like the handle of a mortar: which is not heavy, nor very light.
Deinde ponatur sub infirmo postquam ponuntur super caput ligni panni lenes: et infirmus sit stans secundum longitudinem ligni.	Then the soft cloths will be placed upon the weak one, after they have been placed upon the head of the log: and the weak one should stand according to the length of the log.
Deinde extendatur manus eius ad inferiora a parte altera, et extendatur corpus eius ab altera parte cum fortitudine: nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then his hand and body are extended from the other side, and he is joined with force from the other side, for the dislocation returns to its place with weakness.
Quod si difficilis sit eius reductio per omnia quae diximus, tunc utere hac cura: et est, ut accipias lignum cuius longitudo sit quantitas duorum brachiorum, et eius latitudo quantitas quatuor digitorum, et grossitudo eius quantitas duorum digitorum: cui sit caput rotundum, ut alleuietur introitus eius in profundum titillici, secundum hanc formam.	But if it is difficult for him to be reduced by all that I have said, then use this care: and it should be as if a log whose length is the quantity of two forearms, and whose width is the quantity of four fingers, and whose grossness is the quantity of two fingers: whose head is round, so that the entrance of his wrist may go deep into the hollow of the thumb, according to this form.
Deinde ligentur super caput rotundum panni lenes, ut non laedat lignum infirmum.	Then, they bind a loose linen bandage around the round head, so as not to harm the weak wood.
Deinde ponatur sub titillico infirmi, ut extendatur manus, aut brachium super lignum usque ad inferiora: et ligetur lignum super adiutorium et brachium et extremitatem manus.	Then, they place it under the weak arm or shoulder, so that the hand extends as far as the wooden support; and they tie the wood to the aid and the hand and finger end.
Deinde ponatur brachium super gradum scalae per latitudinem, et extendatur manus ad inferiora, et dimittatur reliquum corpus suspensum a parte altera.	Then, they place the shoulder over the step of the ladder along its length, and the hand extends to the lower parts, while the rest of the body is suspended from the other side.
Iunctura enim ingreditur statim.	The knot is immediately entered.
Cum ergo completur introitus eius secundum quemcunque modum possibile est: tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico spheram aequalis quantitatis ex lana.	When the opening of this is completed according to whatever manner is possible: then it is necessary to place under the weak arm a sphere of equal quantity from wool.
Deinde pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum olibano, et albumine oui super humerum totum, sicut reuoluitur desuper.	Then, place the prepared plaster made from flour with almond and albumin on the entire arm, as it rotates above.
Deinde stringe sub titillico strictura decenti: et reuoluatur ligamentum super emplastrum desuper: et annectatur manus eius ad collum ipsius, et dimittatur, neque moueatur manus eius septem diebus.	Then, tie the narrow bandage according to fit: and the cord rolls above the plaster: and the hand of this is connected to the neck of the same, and it is suspended, and the hand of this does not move for seven days.
Et oportet, ut ponatur cibus infirmipaucus, donec confortetur membrum: quoniam est uelocius ad sanationem eius.	And it is necessary to place a weak food, until the member is strengthened, because it is more suitable for its cure.
Deinde ponatur amplior post septem dies, aut quinque, et ex ercitetur cum motu.	Then, a larger one is placed after seven days, or five, and it is moved with motion.
Si ergo firmatur et non mollificatur, tunc iam sanatus est.	If it holds firm and is not softened, then it is already cured.
Si uero iunctura dislocatur multotiens, propter humiditatem quae accidit ei, aut propter caussam aliam: tunc oportet, ut administretur in ea cauterium cum tribus foraminibus, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo de cauterio.	If the knot is dislocated often due to moisture that occurs to it, or for some other cause: then it is necessary to apply the cauterant with three holes, according to what was mentioned in the chapter of cauterization.
Quod si fiat hoc totum, et soluatur ligamentum post septem dies, et non confirmetur iunctura, et reducatur emplastrum et strictura super ipsum aliquotiens, et non firmetur, et cadat, et non possit eleuare ipsum ad superiora: tunc scias, quod nerui eius qui sunt ad caput humeri, iam incisi sunt, aut extensi, aut mollificati: et scias, quod iunctura nunquam figetur in loco suo.	If this is done entirely, and the cord is loosened after seven days, and the knot does not hold the joint, and the plaster and bandage are applied again several times, and does not hold, and falls, and cannot be raised to its upper part: then you know that the bones of his arm which are near the head of the shoulder, have already been cut, extended, or softened: and you know that the knot is never made in its place.
Dislocationis autem quae fit uersus pectus et mammillam, aut ad posteriora reductio, fit cum impulsione et extensione cum manibus: donec redeat, et administretur in ea reliqua strictura et cura, donec sanetur.	When the breast and nipple are dislocated, or if it is reduced to the back, it is done with a push and extension of the hands. Until it returns, and the remaining tightness and care are given, it will heal.
Quod si accidat post sanationem grauitas in membro, et tarditas in motu eius, tunc utatur infirmus balneo multotiens, donec leniatur illa grauitas, et redeat ad naturam eius primam.	If, after healing, there is old age in the member, and slowness in its movement, then a weak bath is used often, until that old age is relieved and it returns to its original state.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Cubiti.	¶ Treatment of the Dislocation of the Shoulder.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter 28.
Scias, quod iunctura Cubiti dislocatur cum difficultate, et similiter redit cum difficultate etiam: et ipsa quidem dislocatur ad omnes partes, et praecipue ad anteriorem, aut ad posteriorem.	You know that the dislocation of the shoulder is difficult, and it also returns with difficulty, and even so, it is dislocated to all parts, and especially to the front and back.
Et eius dislocatio non occultatur tibi: quoniam est cadens sub uisu, et sub tactu, secundum quamcunque figuram dislocetur.	And its dislocation is not hidden from you: for it is falling under use, and under touch, according to whatever figure it is dislocated.
Et quando coniungis cubitum dislocatum cum sano, declaratur tibi illud manifeste.	And when you reduce the dislocated shoulder to the sound one, that is clearly shown to you.
Concauatur enim iunctura, et non potest duplicare brachium, neque tangere cum eo humerum suum.	The joint is concealed, and it cannot double the shoulder, nor touch its own arm with it.
Et oportet, ut properes, et reducas dislocationem statim, antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And it is necessary to do this as soon as possible, and reduce the dislocation immediately, before it becomes cold apostema.
Nam si accidit ei apostema calidum, difficilis fit eius reductio: et fortasse non sanatur omnino, praecipue quando est ad posteriora.	For if it becomes cold apostema, it is difficult to reduce it: and perhaps it does not heal at all, especially when it is to the back.
Est enim deterior omnibus speciebus dislocationis, et uehementioris doloris eis: et multotiens descendit cum ea mors.	For it is worse in all kinds of dislocations and painful ones: and it often dies with them.
Et restauratio eius quando est ex eis quae possibile est reducere, est, ut extendatur manus eius cum duabus manibus: et brachium eius sit expansum, et manus medici sint supra cubitum et sub eo, et ipse impellat iuncturam cum pollicibus manuum suarum simul, aut cum radice palmae suae, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And the restoration of it is, when it can be reduced, to extend the hand of that member with two hands: and the shoulder of that member is expanded, and the hand of the physician is above the shoulder and under it, and he pushes the joint with the fingers of his own hands simultaneously, or with the root of the palm of his own hand, until it returns to its place.
Aut uero dislocatio est ad anteriora: tunc redit ita, ut duplicet manum cum manu sua, donec percutiat cum radice palmae suae cubitum qui est dislocatus.	If indeed it is a dislocation to the front: then it returns thus, so that the hand doubles with its own hand, until it strikes with the root of its palm, which is dislocated, with the cubit.
Quod si non obedit dislocatio ad reductionem, tunc administra extensionem uehementem, fortem ualde: et est, ut extendant brachium duo ministri: et teneant ipsum duo ministri etiam, ut non remoueatur apud extensionem.	If the dislocation does not submit to reduction, then administer a strong extension, with great force: and it is as if two hands were extending the arm: and hold it firmly by two hands even so that it does not move during the extension.
Deinde reuoluatur brachium ad omnem partem postquam inuoluitur super manum eius pannus duplicatus longus, aut ligamentum latum.	Then the arm is turned over to all parts after it has been reduced on the palm of the hand, whether it be the doubled band or the wide ligament.
Et quando tangit medicus manu sua iuncturam, inungat ipsam cum oleo: ut sit illud ex eis quae adiuuant in lubricitate iuncturae cum facilitate.	And when it touches the physician's hand with the joint, anoint it with oil: so that this be one of those which aid in the ease of the joint with lubricity.
Deinde impellat iuncturam impulsione uehementi, donec redeat.	Then let him press the joint with a strong impulse, until it returns.
Et post reductionem eius oportet, ut ponatur super ipsam emplastrum, in quo sit stipticitas, et exiccatio cum albugine oui: et stringatur strictura decenti.	And after the reduction of it, it is proper that it be laid on the same plaster, wherein there is stipticity, and excitation with the bone, and that it be tied in a proper manner.
Et suspendatur brachium a collo infirmi: et dimitte diebus aliquot.	And hang the arm from the weak neck: and let it be for some days.
Deinde soluatur.	Then it shall be unwound.
Si ergo firmatur iunctura in loco suo, tunc solue ligamentum ab ea, et dimitte ipsam.	If the joint is firm in its place, then unbind the ligament from it, and let it go.
Et si uides iuncturam non bene stringi, tunc itera emplastrum, et ligamentum, et dimitte ipsam diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	And if you see the joint not well to be bound, then repeat the plaster, and the ligament, and let it go for some days, until it be bound.
Deinde solue ipsam.	Then let it go.
Si autem accidit ei grauitas post reductionem iuncturae, et dispositio sit in motu: tunc administra humectationem in balneatione, et fricationem subtilem, et compressionem, donec liniatur, aut pone super iuncturam iliati, id est, natem arietis pinguem.	If however, old age happens to it after the reduction of the joint, and the position is in motion: then administer hydromelaration in the bath, and subtle friction, and compression, until it be tightened, or be laid upon the joint, that is, the fatty nates of the heels.
Deinde ligetur, et dimitte ipsam super eam die et nocte.	Then it is laid on, and let it be given to her day and night.
Deinde aufer eam, et intromitte ipsum in balneum.	Then take it away, and then insert it into the bath.
Cum ergo sudat, tunc frica iuncturam fricatione temperata.	When she is washing, then rub the joined friction with gentle heat.
Deinde itera super ipsam aleliati uice una, et secunda, et tertia cum introitu balnei, donec leniatur.	Then repeat over her affected part three times, and second time, and third time after inserting into the bath, until it becomes soft.
Et si uis, pone super ipsam stercus uaccinum, humidum, calefactum cum butyro, et stringe super ipsum.	And if you will, place over her excrement a moist, heated buttermilk with care, and tie it over it.
Fac illud aliquotiens.	Do this several times.
Ipsa namque lenitur, et redit ad dispositionem suam.	She will become softened, and return to its original position.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Almahassem.	¶ About the treatment of Almahassem dislocations.
Caput XXIX.	Caput XXIX.
Mahassem manus multotiens dislocatur, id est, iunctura quae est inter brachium et manum.	The hand of Mahassem is often dislocated, that is, the joint between the shoulder and the arm.
Et reductio dislocationis eius est facilis.	And the reduction of her dislocation is easy.
Econtrario reliquarum iuncturarum.	And the other joints are difficult to reduce.
Verumtamen oportet, ut uelocitas sit in reductione dislocationis eius in hora in qua dislocatur, antequam apostemetur locus: aut accidat in eo apostema calidum.	Nevertheless, it is necessary that the ease of reduction of her dislocated hand be in the hour in which it is dislocated, before the wound is closed: or it happens at the same time as the heat of the wound.
Et reductio dislocationis in eo est, ut ponas Mahassem manus infirmae super tabulam, et extendat minister manum eius: et ponat medicus palmam suam super eminentiam iuncturae, et impellat eam, donec redeat.	And the reduction of her dislocated hand is that you place Mahassem's weak hand over the table, and extend her other hand: and the physician places his palm over the prominence of the joint, and presses it until it returns.
Verumtamen oportet, ut consyderetur, si palma iam recessit ad uentrem manus: tunc ponat infirmus dorsum manus suae super tabulam apud extensionem et reductionem: et si dislocatio est procedens ad dorsum manus, tunc sit positio manus eius intrinsece super tabulam, id est, interior pars manus eius super tabulam ponatur, ut cadat manus medici super ipsam eminentiam iuncturae.	Nevertheless, it is necessary that it be considered, if the palm has already returned to the chest of the hand: then she places her weak back over the table at the extension and reduction: and if the dislocation is proceeding to the back of the hand, then the position of her hand is intrinsic over the table, that is, the interior part of her hand is placed over the prominence of the joint, so that the hand of the physician falls on its own prominence of the joint.
Si ergo redit statim, bonum est: et si non, tunc stringe eam cum emplastro sedante apostema: et dimitte ipsum, neque iteres illud.	If it returns immediately, that is good: and if not, then grasp it with a plaster while it is seated post-amputation, and let it go, do not repeat this.
Nam si non tolerat, neque potes super reductionem eius, postquam praetereunt ei dies, uerumtamen iunctura remanet secundum tortuositatem suam: et non nocet infirmo aliquid, nisi quod mollificatur manus, et non potest stringere aliquid: tunc scias, quod nerui sunt abscissi, aut attriti.	If it does not bear the reduction, nor can you perform it after three days have passed, nevertheless the union remains according to its twists and turns: and nothing harms the patient except that the hand is softened, and nothing can be tightened: then you know that the nerves are either cut or torn.
Non est ergo ingenium in ea, nisi ut stringatur cum cauterio prope casum eius.	Therefore, there is no genius in this, unless it is tied with a cauterant near its wound.
Et fortasse non confert illud aliquid.	And perhaps it does not harm anything.
Cum ergo non redit Almahassem, tunc pone super ipsum emplastrum, quod narrauimus.	When Almahassem does not return, then place the plaster we mentioned above on it.
Deinde stringatur, et dimittatur quinque diebus: postea soluatur et dimittatur, et exercitetur manus.	Then it is tied and released for five days: after that, it is loosened and released, and the hand is exercised.
Si autem priuatur motus eius, et accidat in ea aliquid grauitatis: tunc leni eam cum aqua calefacta, et fricatione aliquotiens, donec leniatur.	If however the movement of it is impeded, and something of stiffness occurs in it: then soothe it with warm water, and friction several times, until it is eased.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Digitorum.	¶ Treatment of the Dislocation of the Digits.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Quando dislocatur ex eis Digitus ad omnem partem, uel ex eis Digitus ad dorsum palmae, aut uentrem eius: tunc extende Digitum, et impelle dislocationem pollicibus tuis, donec redeat.	When a digit is dislocated from one of them to all parts, or from one of them to the back of the palm, or to its ventrum: then extend the digit with your fingers, and press the displacement with your fingers until it returns.
Deinde sustenta caput Digiti, et suspende ipsum uersus partem ad quam dislocatur, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	Then support the head of the digit, and suspend the opposite part to which it is dislocated for two days, and let it go.
Deinde suspende eum, et extende ipsum, donec aequetur rectus in illo die suo.	Then suspend it, and extend it until it is straight in its own day.
Cum ergo fuerit nox, liga ipsum secundum narrationem ipsam: et non cesses soluere ipsum in die: et exerce eum cum motu: et liga ipsum in nocte.	When it is night, tie it according to the description: and do not cease to loosen it in the day: and exercise it with motion: and tie it at night.
Fac illud diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	This should be done after a few days, once it is tightened.
Et similiter fac cum eo, si dislocatur ad uentrem manus: et liga eum ad partem ipsam, et fac cum eo operationem tuam primam, donec sanetur.	And similarly, when it is dislocated to the ventrum of the hand: and tie it to the same part, and perform your first operation with it, until it heals.
Et similiter fac cum eo quando dislocatur ad reliquas partes.	And similarly, when it is dislocated to other parts: and perform your operation as before.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Spondilium dorsi.	¶ Regarding the treatment of dislocation of the dorsal spine.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31.
Quando accidit alicui Spondilium dorsi, aut colli dislocatio completa, aut remouentur Spondiles multae a locis suis: tunc non est in ea curatio, quoniam mors properat infirmo.	When a dorsal spine dislocation occurs, or a complete dislocation of the collarbone, or many vertebrae are moved from their places: then there is no cure for it, because death comes to the weak.
Et signum illius est, quod egestio infirmi egreditur absque uoluntate, neque potest tenere eam: et multotiens mollificantur ex eo quaedam membra eius, aut duo crura eius, aut duo brachia ipsius, aut unum eorum: aut remouetur Spondilis una de loco suo.	And the sign of this is that the weak ones go out without will, and cannot hold it, and often some of their limbs are made soft by it, or both thighs, or both arms of his, or one of them: or the dislocation is removed from its place.
Multotiens enim remouetur, quod multotiens fit remotio earum ad quatuor partes.	For it is often removed because it is often removed to four parts.
Illa ergo quae remouetur ad posteriora, nominatur Gibbositas.	Therefore, that which is removed to the posterior part, is called gibbosity.
Curatio uero eius est, ut consyderes tunc, si Gibbositas accidit a puericia: tunc non est in ea curatio, neque ex ea est sanatio omnino.	The treatment of this is that you should consider then, if gibbosity occurs from infancy: then there is no cure for it, nor is there any healing at all.
In illa autem quae accidit a casu, aut percussione, aut similibus illis, iam dixerunt antiqui modos curationis sermone prolixo.	But in those which happen from accident, or blow, or similar things, the ancients have already spoken of the methods of curing with a long discourse.
Cuius plurimum non redit cum proficuo.	Which is not returned with profit.
Ego uero iam abbreuiaui ex illo, cuius parum excusat a multo eius ex propinquitate mea ad intentionem: et expositione mea qua exposui illud, et formaui instrumentum eius diuerso modo ab eo quo ostenderunt illud, et exposuerunt ipsum.	I have already abbreviated from that, which is not excused by much of its proximity to my own: and from my exposure, in which I showed it, and formed the instrument of it in a different way from what they showed it, and they also exposed it.
Dico ergo, quod in gibbositate quae accidit ab anteriori parte, non est ingenium, neque sanatio ex ea.	I declare that there is no genius or cure from such a tumor that occurs from the front part.
Et similiter in illa quae fit ad duo latera etiam.	And similarly, in those that occur to both sides, also.
Et non curatur ex eis, nisi illa quae accidit in dorso proprie, cum eo quod ego narro: et est, ut extendatur infirmus super faciem suam super podium aequale prope parietem: et expandatur sub eo stramentum humidum, ut non laedatur pectus eius.	And it is not cured from them, unless those that happen in the back properly, as I say: and it is, that the weak extends over its face above the podium equal to the wall near the parietum: and it is expanded under it with a wet humid stramentum, so that it does not hurt the chest of its.
Deinde ponatur lignum rectum fixum in fouea in terra, in extremitate podii, circiter caput eius: et lignum aliud circiter pedes eius in extremitate altera podii: et minister teneat lignum, et sit non firmatum in fouea.	Then a straight log is placed fixed in the fork on the ground, at the end of the foot, near the head of its: and another log, approximately at the other end of its foot: and it holds the log, and it is not firm in the fork.
Et minister alter teneat alterum.	And it holds the other.
Deinde inuolue super caput infirmi, et sub titillicis eius ligamentum lene, firmum: et extende extremitatem ligamenti ad lignum quod est apud caput eius: et liga ipsum in eo.	Then it covers over the weak head, and under the loose ligament of its, gently firm, and extends the end of the ligament to the log that is at its head: and it ties it in it.
Deinde stringe ligamentum aliud supra anchas eius, et supra genua ipsius, et apud cauillas eius.	Then it ties another ligament above its loose belly, and above its knees, and at its thighs.
Deinde aggrega ligamenta omnia, et liga ea in ligno altero quod est apud pedes eius.	Then it gathers all the ligaments together, and ties them in the other log that is at its feet.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem ligni ligamentum, et non remoueantur duo ligna ex locis suis in quibus sunt fixa: uerumtamen non sint firmata, sicut diximus.	Then it extends all the helper to the part of the log ligament, and the two logs are not removed from their places where they are fixed: however they are not firm as I say.
Et medicus ponat palmas suas super Spondilem cum fortitudine, donec redeat: aut ponat super eam tabulam.	And the physician will put his hands over the spine with strength, until he returns: or he will put over it a table.
Deinde annectat super tabulam pedes suos, donec redeat.	Then he will connect above the table his feet, until he returns.
Si autem non redit per hanc curationem, tunc accipe tabulam cuius longitudo sit circiter tria brachia.	If however he does not return by this cure, then take the table whose length is approximately three arms.
Et caua in pariete de quo diximus quod est prope infirmum, locum in quem ingrediatur extremitas tabulae.	The causa in the wall from which we said that it is near the weakest part, is the place where the extremity of the tablet enters.
Deinde pone medium tabulae super Spondilem.	Then place the middle of the tablet over the spine.
Et ponat pedes suos medicus super extremitatem alteram.	And the physician will place his feet on the opposite extremity.
Et stringat bene, donec coartetur Spondilis, et redeat ad locum suum.	And tie it well, until the spine coils around, and return to its own place.
Deinde si uis, operare cum torno quod inuoluitur cum manu tua: et est, ut figas in terram apud caput infirmi in postremo podii duo ligna, quorum longitudo sit brachii unius: et apud caput eius in postremo podii duo ligna.	Then, if you wish, to operate with the turned part of the arm that is covered by your hand: and it should be as if you are placing two sticks in the ground near the weakest part of the foot, in the final part of the two legs, whose length is equal to the bicep of one: and near the head of this foot in the final part of the two legs.
Et sit longitudo quae est inter omne lignum palmus unus: et iam factum est in omni loco foramen, in quo currit tornum: et firmetur lignum omne in terra multum, ne moueatur omnino.	And the length that is between all the sticks of one palm: and it has already been made in every place where the turned part runs: and the entire stick should be firmly placed on the ground much, so that it does not move at all.
Et intromittatur lignum rotundum: et est tornum in quo reuoluitur ligamentum in duobus foraminibus duorum lignorum.	And the round stick should be inserted: and it is the turned part in which the ligament rotates in two holes of two sticks.
Et in extremitate eius est foramen, in quo firmatur lignum, cuius longitudo est palmus cum eo quod reuoluitur: et in duobus lignis aliis est similiter illius.	And at the extreme end of it is a hole, in which the stick is firmly placed, whose length is equal to the palm of that one with which it rotates, and in two other sticks it is similar to this.
Deinde stringe ligamenta quae strinxisti in pectore infirmi torno quod est apud caput eius: et ligamenta quae strinxisti in cruribus eius in torno quod est apud pedes eius.	Then tie the ligaments that you have tied in the weak chest with the turned part that is near the head of this foot: and tie the ligaments that you have tied in the legs with the turned part that is near the feet of this leg.
Deinde stet apud omne tornum minister, qui torqueat manum suam cum licinio, cum quo reuoluitur tornum: et medicus aequet Spondilem, secundum quod diximus.	Then stand near all the turned parts that turn the hand with the thumb, with which it rotates: and the physician should place the spine according to what we have said.
Haec est forma torni, quae sequitur.	This is the form of the turned part that follows.
Deinde postquam redit Spondilis, et aequatur locus, tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum exiccatiuum cum albumine oui.	Then, after the sponge has returned, and the place is prepared, it is then necessary to put on a plaster of ichthyol with albumen.
Deinde stuppam.	Then, apply the stupe.
Postea pone supra emplastrum astellam ex tabula, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, aut circiter eos.	Then, place above the plaster a star-shaped piece of paper, whose width is three digits or about them.
Et longitudo eius quantitas quae capiat locum Gibbositatis, et super partem Spondilis sanae.	And the length of it should be such that it takes up the place of Gibbosity, and over a part of the healthy sponge.
Deinde ligetur cum ligamento quod diximus.	Then, it is wrapped with the tie we have mentioned.
Et utatur infirmus nutrimento subtili, donec sanetur.	And a weak nourishment of fine substance is used until it heals.
Quod si remaneat quiddam eminentiae in loco in fine sanationis: tunc oportet, ut administrentur medicinae quae mollificant, et leniunt, cum administratione tabulae quam narrauimus tempore longo.	If there remains some prominence in the place at the end of healing: then it is necessary to administer medicines that soften and ease, with the administration of the paper we have mentioned for a long time.
Et iam administratur in illo lamina plumbi.	And already, lead is being administered in that layer.
Et quandoque accidit eminentia in postremo Spondilium dorsi: et putatur per eam dislocatio, et est illud os quod iam eminet.	And sometimes, a prominence occurs at the end of the spine of the back: and it is supposed to be a displacement, and that is the bone that has already protruded.
Quare non oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei cum hac medicina: fortasse enim accidere faciet mortem.	Therefore, it is not necessary for a presumption to be made in him with this medicine: perhaps it will cause death.
¶ De curatione Anchae dislocatae.	¶ About the treatment of Anchae's dislocation.
Caput XXXII.	¶ Head 32.
Scias, quod iuncturae Anchae, et iuncturae humeri, non accidit, nisi dislocatio tantum: neque accidit eis quod accidit reliquis iuncturis ex remotione parua, et concauitate.	You know that the joints of Anchae and the joints of the elbow do not happen unless it is a dislocation only: nor does it happen to them that happens to other joints from removal and concoction.
Et iunctura quidem Anchae dislocatur secundum quatuor partes.	And the joint of Anchae does indeed dislocate according to four parts.
Quod est, quia dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	That is, because it is dislocated to the front and back.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur ad interiora: et parum dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	And it is most dislocated to the inside: and it is least dislocated to the front and back.
Et curatio dislocationis eius ad interiora, est: quia quando tu coniungis crus infirmi sanum cum infirmo, est longius: et est genu eius eminens plus quam sani, et non potest infirmus duplicare pedem suum apud inguen: et est locus qui sequitur inguen apostematus apostemate calido, propterea, quod caput coxae iam peruenit illic.	The treatment for this dislocation is to bring the joint inwards because when you join a weak bone with a healthy one, it is further apart: and the knee of this patient is higher than the healthy one, and the weak cannot double its step at the groin: and there is a place that follows the groin, which is burned after the thigh bone is struck, therefore, because the head of the hip has already become wet there.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad exteriora est, quod sunt accidentia eius contraria istis accidentibus.	The sign of this dislocation that occurs on the outside is what are its opposite events.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad anteriora, est, quia expandit crus sanum secundum complementum: uerumtamen non duplicat ipsum absque dolore qui est in genu: et si conatur ad ambulandum, non potest super illud ad anteriora: et retinetur urina eius, et apostematur inguen eius, et apud ambulationem est calcatio eius super calcaneum.	The sign of this dislocation that occurs on the front is because the healthy bone expands according to the complement: nevertheless, it does not double itself without pain in the knee: and if it attempts to walk, it cannot go over that to the front: and it retains its urine, and it strikes the groin of its own, and there is a cushioning of its own above the heel during walking.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad posteriora est, ut non expandat genu, neque possit duplicare ipsum antequam duplicet inguen: et est crus eius etiam breuius altero: et inguen est mollificatum, et est caput coxae apud locum ilii.	The sign of this dislocation that occurs on the back is that it does not expand the knee, and it cannot double it before doubling the groin: and the bone of its own is also shorter on the other side: and the groin is softened, and the head of the hip is at the place of that.
Reductio uero huius dislocationis specierum est, ut consyderes tunc, si dislocatio est uetusta, quae iam antiquatur cum habente ipsam.	The reduction of this dislocation is as follows: that you consider then, if the dislocation is old, which has been for a long time with having it.
Deinde si tu administres reductionem eius, et remanet secundum dispositionem suam: tunc non est in ea curatio omnino.	Then, if you perform the reduction of this dislocation and it remains according to its own disposition: then there is no cure at all in it.
Non ergo oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei penitus.	Therefore, it does not follow that there should be a presumption of its being completely reduced.
In illo autem cuius dislocatio est recens, et est ex una specierum quatuor dislocationis: tunc propera ad hoc, ut uoluas iuncturam, et extendas ipsam ad interiora et ad exteriora, et moueas eam dextra et sinistra: fortasse enim redit, et non indiget alia cura.	In that one whose dislocation is recent and is of one of the four kinds of dislocations: then, in order to this, if you wish to join it, extend it both towards the interior and towards the exterior, and move it right and left: perhaps it will return, and there will be no need for another care.
Si autem non redit hoc modo, tunc oportet, ut praepares ministrum fortem, et extendat crus eius ab inferiori parte: aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento, quod ligetur super crus eius supra genu: et minister alius extendat manum eius desuper, ita ut intromittat manus suas sub titillicis eius.	If this method does not return, then it is necessary to prepare a strong servant and extend the thigh of his crus from below: either with his own hands or with the bandage that is laid on top of his crus above the knee: and another servant extends his hand over his, so that he inserts his hand under the shinbone of his.
Deinde stringat cum ligamento leni super radicem coxae, et teneat extremitatem ligamenti alterius.	Then he should tighten with a soft bandage over the hip bone and hold the other end of the bandage.
Et sit extensio eius aut ab anteriori parte inguinis ad partem furculae, aut a posteriori ad partem dorsi.	And it should be extended either from the front of the thigh to the shoulder, or from the back to the back.
Et sit extensio eorum omnium uice una, donec eleuetur infirmus cum corpore suo a terra, et remaneat pendens.	And it should be extended uniformly until the weak one lifts his body off the ground and hangs down.
Et haec enim species extensionis est species communis specierum quatuor.	This is the species of extension, which is common to the four species.
Si ergo redit dislocatio cum eo quod diximus, est bonum: et si non, tunc necesse est omni speciei illud quod dicam de curatione propria.	If this dislocation returns with the one I mentioned earlier, it is good: and if not, then it is necessary for the entire species that I will mention for the treatment of this.
In reductione quidem eius propria quando dislocatio est ad interiora, oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super latus suum sanum.	In the reduction of this, when the dislocation is towards the inside, it is necessary that the weak one hangs down on his own healthy side.
Deinde ponat ligamentum super radicem coxae, in eo quod est inter caput coxae, et locum qui est sub inguine.	Then he should put the bandage over the hip bone, in the place that is between the head of the hip and the place under the thigh.
Deinde extende ligamentum ad sursum a parte inguinis ad altiorem partem corporis, ad partem furculae.	Then he should extend the bandage upwards from the thigh to the higher part of the body, to the shoulder.
Deinde accipiat minister alius fortis brachia eius, et minuat locum grossum coxae infirmae, et extendat ad exteriora extensione uehementi.	Then he should take a strong servant's arm and reduce the place of the weak thigh, and extend it with a strong extension.
Iam enim redit ad locum suum.	Now it returns to its own place.
Et haec species est facilioris reliquis speciebus curationis, qua reducitur hoc membrum.	This is the easiest of the others in the treatment of this member.
Si autem excusatur super te, et non obedit tibi ad introitum cum hac specie curationis omnino: tunc oportet, ut ligentur duo pedes infirmi simul cum ligamento forti, leni, super duos calcaneos, et super duo genua: et sit longitudo cuiusque a compare suo quantitatis quatuor digitorum: et sit crus infirmum extensum plus altero quantitate duorum digitorum.	If however it is excused from you, and does not obey you to enter with this species of treatment entirely: then it is necessary that two weak feet be tied together with a strong but soft bandage over the two heels, and over the two knees: and the length of each should be according to the quantity of four toes: and the weak leg should be extended more than twice the quantity of two toes.
Deinde suspendatur infirmus super caput ligni, quod sit in domo: et sit longitudo eius a terra quantitas duorum brachiorum.	Then the weak one is hanged over the head of the wooden beam that is in the house, and its length is as much as two arms.
Deinde praecipe iuueni forti, ut muniat caput coxae: et suspendatur cum infirmo inuenis alius: et impellat iuuenis alius, muniens coxam cum fortitudine, nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then the strong youth is commanded to cover the head of the thighs, and it is hung with the weak one on another: and the strong youth presses the other, covering the thighs with strength, for the joint returns to its own place with weakness.
In reditione autem eius propria, quando est dislocatio ad exteriora, oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super podium, secundum quod narrauimus in habente gibbositatem.	In the reduction of its own kind, when it is dislocated to the outside, it is necessary that the weak one lies over the foot, according to what we have said about having a knob.
Et stringatur ligamentum super crus eius, infirmum proprie, et super pectus eius.	And the bandage is tied over the thigh of the weak one, properly, and over his breast.
Deinde ponantur duo ligna, unum apud pedes eius, et alterum apud caput ipsius.	Then two beams are placed, one at his foot, and another at his head.
Deinde ponatur lignum additum in medio podii, fixum bene: super quod inuoluti sint panni humidi, ut non laedat infirmum: et sit lignum inter coxas eius, ut non attrahatur ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then a additional beam is placed in the middle of the foot, fixed well: over which the wet belts are placed so that it does not hurt the weak one: and the beam should be between the thighs of the weak one so that it does not attract to the lower parts during extension.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem suam, et medicus aequet reductionem manu sua.	Then all the helpers extend to their own part, and the physician applies the reduction with his hand.
Si ergo obedit ad reuersionem, erit bonum.	If then he obeys to the reuersion, it will be good.
Et si non, pone super ipsam tabulam, et preme ipsam, sicut diximus in gibbositate, aequaliter.	And if not, place over the same table, and press it, as we have said about the knob, equally.
Verumtamen oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	However, it is necessary that the weak one lies over his sound side.
Et quando dislocatio est ad anteriora, tunc oportet, ut extendatur crus infirmi uelociter: et est secundum hanc eandem narrationem super podium: et ponat medicus palmam manus suae dextrae super inguen infirmum.	And when the dislocation is to the front, then it is necessary that the weak thigh is extended widely: and this is according to the same report over the foot: and the physician places his right hand palm on the weak groin.
Deinde coartet ipsum cum manu altera, et cum illa coartatione pone ipsum extensum ad inferiora ad partem genu.	Then he bends it with his other hand, and with that bending places the extended one to the lower parts of the knee to the part of the leg.
Et si dislocatio est ad posteriora: tunc non oportet, ut extendatur infirmus ad inferiora, et sit eleuatus super terram: imo oportet, ut sit positus super rem duram, sicut oportet, ut fit etiam si dislocatur ancha eius ad exteriora, secundum illud quod diximus de accubitu eius super duas anchas: et est super faciem eius, et ligamenta extensa: secundum quod diximus nuper.	If the dislocation is to the back: then it does not necessitate that the weak one extend to the lower parts, and that he be raised above the ground: indeed, it is necessary that he be placed above the hard thing, just as it is necessary that he be placed in that position even if the dislocation is far outward, according to what we said about his reclining on two of its sides: and he is above his face, and the ligaments are extended: according to what we said earlier.
Et oportet, ut administretur compressio cum tabula etiam super locum ad quem egreditur iunctura, cum completur reductio secundum quod oportet.	And it is necessary that the compression be given with the table even when he is on his way to the place of the joint, when the reduction is complete according to what is necessary.
Et signum reditionis eius non occultatur tibi: et est, ut extendas duo crura infirmi: et quando uides ea aequalia, et infirmus stringit crus suum, et expandit ipsum absque excusatione: tunc scias, quia iam redit membrum, secundum quod oportet: tunc coniunge duas coxas, et pone emplastrum, et stringe cum imemati, id est, rota: ita, ut non moueatur ancha ad aliquam partium: et adhaereat infirmus quieti tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	And the sign of his reduction is not hidden from you: and it is that he extends the two weak legs: and when you see them equal, and the weak one draws in his leg, and expands it without excuse, then you know that the member has returned according to what is necessary: then join the two thighs, and put on plaster, and tie with a tight roll, that is, a ring: thus, so that it does not move too far to any part: and it adheres quietly for three or four days, or five.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et emplastrum, et compara crus cum altero: tunc si uides ea aequalia in statu, tunc scias, quod dislocatio iam firmata est: absolue ergo infirmum ad ambulandum.	Then loosen the ligament, and the plaster, and compare the leg with the other: then if you see them equal in state, then you know that the dislocation is now firm: therefore, let the weak one walk.
Et si uides aliquid mollificationis: tunc redi, et emplastra illud, et stringe illud secundum stricturam tuam primam: et dimitte illud etiam tribus diebus.	And if you see something of softening: then return, and the plaster that, and tie it according to your first tightness: and let him be without it for three days.
Deinde solue illud et fac ipsum tardare in ambulatione super utrumque aliquot diebus, donec confortetur bene.	Then loosen that and make him walk slowly over a few days on both sides, until he is well recovered.
¶ De dislocationis Genu.	¶ Of the Dislocation of the Knee.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter XXXIII.
Genu dislocatur secundum tres modos.	The knee is dislocated in three ways.
Dislocatur ad exteriora, ad interiora, et ad inferiora, scilicet ad posteriora.	The knee is dislocated externally, internally, and towards the lower part, that is, towards the back.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora.	And it is not dislocated towards the front.
Et signum dislocationis eius, est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut applicet crus suum ad coxam suam.	And the sign of its dislocation is that it makes the limb weaker, that it applies its own knee to its hip.
Si autem non adhaeret cum coxa: tunc scias, quod Genu est dislocatum.	But if it does not adhere to the hip: then you know that the knee is dislocated.
Et restauratio omnium modorum dislocationis eius est, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum, ita ut iam extendat crus suum si potest super illud, et adhaeret dorsum tuum ad faciem eius: et pone pedem eius inter pedes tuos.	And the restoration of all modes of its dislocation is that you make the weak limb sit upright, so that it may extend its knee if possible over that, and your back may adhere to its face: and place its foot between your feet.
Deinde adhaerere fac Genu eius cum palmis tuis, et recta eas inter digitos tuos super Genu eius.	Then make it adhere with your fingers to the knee of that leg, and make them straight over the knee of that leg.
Deinde applica cum palma tua duo latera Genu eius cum fortitudine.	Then apply with your finger the two sides of the knee of that leg with strength.
Et minister alius extendat pedem eius, donec redeat Genu ad locum suum.	And another may extend its foot until it returns to its place.
Et signum reditionis est, ut adhaereat crus cum coxa in lenitate, non laboriose.	And the sign of returning is that it adheres with the knee to the hip, not laboriously.
Deinde emplastra ipsum, et adhaerere fac crus cum coxa.	Then apply the plaster itself, and make it adhere with the knee to the hip.
Deinde liga ea simul cum uitta tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	Then bind it together for three or four days.
Deinde solue ea.	Then untie it.
Et non utatur infirmus ambulatione aliquot diebus, donec sanetur.	And it should not be used for weak walking for a few days until it is cured.
Si autem recusatur tibi reductio eius, tunc administra extensionem fortem cum ligamentis, quorum praecessit narratio in curatione anchae, donec redeat.	But if it refuses your return, then apply a strong extension with the ligaments which I have mentioned in the treatment of the anchylosis, until it returns.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Calcanei.	¶ Treatment of the Dislocation of the Heel (Calcaneus)
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter XXXIV.
Calcaneus quandoque remouetur remotione parua, et quandoque dislocatur secundum complementum.	The heel is sometimes removed by a small removal, and sometimes it is dislocated according to the complement.
Et dislocatio eius fit, aut ad interiora, aut ad exteriora.	The dislocation of this bone either occurs towards the inner part, or towards the outer part.
Et signum dislocationis eius est, quod uides Calcaneum inflatum, procedentem ad partem ad quam dislocatur.	The sign of this dislocation is what you see, the heel swollen and proceeding towards the part to which it is dislocated.
Curatio autem remotionis eius, est facilis reditionis: et est, ut extendatur cum facilitate cum manibus, et aequetur, donec redeat.	The treatment of this dislocation, however, is an easy reduction: and it is such that it extends with ease with the hands, and becomes equal, until it returns.
In curatione autem eius quando dislocatur secundum complementum, oportet, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum: et teneat ipsum minister fortis ualde a posteriori parte dorsi eius, in medio ipsius.	In the treatment, however, when it is dislocated according to the complement, it is necessary that you make the weak one sit upright: and hold it with a strong assistant from the posterior part of its back, in the middle of it.
Deinde tene tu cum manu tua dextra pedem eius a superiori parte eius, et cum manu tua sinistra ab inferiori parte pedis eius loco cauillae.	Then hold it with your right hand leg of it from the upper part of it, and with your left hand from the lower part of its foot in the place of the knee.
Deinde trahe pedem ad tecum manu tua dextra.	Then draw the foot towards you with your right hand.
Deinde cum sinistra duabus uicibus.	Then with your left two fingers.
Deinde extende cum sinistra, et impelle pectus pedis cum dextra uersus crus absque labore.	Then extend it with your left hand, and press the chest of the foot with your right hand without effort.
Fac illud bis, sicut narrauimus.	Do this twice, as we have said.
Deinde impelle pectus pedis ad crus in uice tertia, et tu trahis cauillam.	Then press the chest of the foot towards the third finger of your hand, and you will draw the knee.
Si ergo redit in uice una, aut in duabus secundum hunc modum, et uides pedem aequatum, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera operationem super ipsum: quoniam ipse redit.	If, therefore, it returns to the third finger of your hand, or to two of them, and you see the foot equal, it is good: and if not, then you must repeat the operation on it, because it returns itself.
Si autem prohibetur tibi reductio eius cum eo quod narrauimus: tunc fac iacere infirmum super dorsum suum super terram, et fige paxillum in terra firmatum ualde, ut cadat inter coxas eius: et tu iam inuoluisti super ipsum pannum, ut non laedat infirmum.	If, however, it is forbidden to you the reduction of it with that which we have said: then make the weak one lie on its back over its own back on the earth, and fasten a bandage on the firm earth in the way that it falls between the legs of it: and you have already covered it with the bandage over it, so that it does not hurt the weak one.
Deinde accipiat minister coxam eius: postea extendat minister alter pedem, aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento quod liget super collum pedis.	Then the assistant takes the other leg of it: then extend the assistant's other foot, either with his own hands, or with a bandage that lies on the neck of its foot.
Deinde extendat omnis minister contra extensionem comparis sui: et paxillus sit stans inter duas coxas infirmi retinens eum, ut non attrahatur corpus eius ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then the surgeon extends his hand against the extension of the patient's limb: and a thin rod is placed between the two weak legs, holding it, so that it does not attract the body of the patient to the lower part during the extension.
Deinde aequet medicus dislocationem manibus suis, et minister alter teneat crus sanum ad inferiora.	Then the surgeon reduces the dislocation of his hands, and another holds the sound leg to the lower part.
Nam dislocatio redit cum uelocitate.	For dislocation returns with weakness.
Quando ergo redit dislocatio, et declaratur tibi sanitas reditionis eius: tunc pone emplastrum et stuppam, et stringe ipsam cum ligamentis firmiter, et liga pedem cum ligamento ad crus.	When then dislocation returns and the health of his return is declared to you: then place the plaster and ointment, and tightly tie it with the firm ligaments, and tie the foot with the ligament to the sound leg.
Et oportet, ut caueas uel timeas de neruis, qui sunt supra calcaneum posterius, ut non sit ligamentum super eos uehemens, et laedat eos.	And it is necessary that you be careful or fear that the nerves which are above the heel posterior, so that the ligament does not become over them, and hurt them.
Deinde dimitte ipsum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then release it to two or three days.
Quod si mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum: deinde solue ipsum in die tertio, aut quarto: et prohibe infirmum ab ambulatione quadraginta diebus.	If the ligament is softened, tie it up again: then untie it on the third or fourth day: and forbid the weak one to walk for forty days.
Si uero conatur ambulare ante illud spacium, non fit securitas quin dissoluatur super ipsum dislocatio, et corrumpatur, et non recipiat post illud curationem.	If however he dares to walk before that time, it does not ensure safety that the ligament will not be dissolved over the dislocation, and it will become corrupted, and will not receive after that treatment.
Quod si accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc oportet, ut administres in sedatione eius illud, in quo praecessit narratio nostra in alio loco ex curatione, et embrocationem, donec remoueatur.	If however a hot afterburn occurs to him: then it is necessary that you administer to his sedative this, which precedes our narrative of care in another place from our treatment, and ointment, until it is removed.
¶ De dislocatione Digitorum pedis, et cura.	¶ About the dislocation of the fingers of the foot, and care.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter XXXV.
Oportet, ut aequetur quod dislocatur ex eis cum extensione pauca absque labore: et illud quidem non est difficile, imo est facile.	It is necessary that it be equal to what is dislocated from them with the extension of a few without labor: and this indeed is not difficult, but rather easy.
Si autem dislocatio est in quibusdam nodis dorsi pedis: tunc oportet, ut faciat sedere infirmus pedem suum super locum aequalem terrae, aut super tabulam: et est stans sicut ambulans.	If however the dislocation is in some nodules of the back of the foot: then it is necessary that he make sit down the weak leg of his on a place equal to the earth, or on a table: and stand as walking.
Deinde tu sta, et pone pedem tuum super illud quod eminet ex illis iuncturis.	Then stand still and place your foot on that which is being discussed among those joints.
Deinde calca illud cum pede tuo cum uirtute, donec redeat, et uideas ipsum iam aequatum, et non appareat in loco eminentia.	Then heat that with your foot using all your strength until it returns to its original state, and you will see that it is already even and does not appear as if it has an eminence.
Deinde pone sub uentre pedis eius tabulam quae capiat pedem totum, cui sint duo capita.	Then place under your foot the tablet that will take the whole foot, which has two heads.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti tribus diebus.	Then tighten it in accordance with the fit that is proper after three days.
Deinde solue ipsum, et fac quiescere eum ab ambulatione diebus multis, donec stringatur et securetur a reductione.	Then dissolve it and make it quiet from walking for many days until it is tightened and secured from the reduction.
¶ De speciebus dislocationis cum uulnere uel fractura.	¶ About the kinds of dislocations with a fracture.
Caput XXXVI.	Caput XXXVI.
Quando accidit aliquid ex illo, et conaris curationem eius, et ipsius restaurationem, multotiens succedit mors: et propter illud non oportet, ut praesumat super curationem eius, quod est huiusmodi, nisi qui est prudens in arte longi usus, misericors, pius, tardus, non audax, neque praesumptuosus: et ut utatur in incaeptionce medicinis quae sedant apostemata calida tantum: et dimittat infirmum diuino iudicio.	When something happens from that, and you take care of its cure and its restoration, death often follows: and therefore it is not proper to assume the cure of that kind without a very experienced physician who is prudent, merciful, pious, slow, not bold, nor presumptuous: and to use in medicines that are settled and hot only: and to let the weak one be judged by divine discernment for a long time.
Nisi uideas, aut speras salutem a perditione cum lenitate aegritudinis, et in quo apparet quiddam spei.	Unless you see, or hope for health from the salvation of pain with the easing of the disease, and in which something seems to be hoped for.
Conare ergo reductionem eius statim in principio rei, antequam accidat apostema calidum.	Therefore, let the reduction of that be attempted at once in the beginning of the matter, before the hot aposteme comes.
Si ergo redit membrum, secundum quod uolumus, tunc administra regimen quod sedat apostema: et cura uulnus cum eo quod conuenit ei ex unguentis desiccatiuis.	If then the member returns as we wish, at that time administer the regimen which soothes the hot aposteme: and cure the knee with it which agrees with him from dried unguents.
Quod si dislocatio est cum fractura, et accidunt in osse satagiae separatae, tunc conare ablationem earum, et fac in illo quod diximus in aegritudinibus simplicibus ex eo quod praecessit in locis earum.	If then the dislocation is with a fracture, and they happen in the separated bones of the dead, at that time let us attempt the removal of them, and let us do in that what I have said about simple diseases in those places from which they precede.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, et custodi teipsum ab introitu in uiam timoris: secundum quod praecessit praedicatio mea tibi.	According to your virtue, and to keep you safe from the beginning to the end of your life, and from the fear of death: according to which my prediction precedes.
Nam illud est melius tibi apud Creatorem tuum, et magis permanens ad gloriam tuam, et magis saluum tuo corpori apud illos in tuo tempore.	For that is better for you before God, and more enduring to your glory, and more safe for your body among them in their time.
